response.answer_text: I loved doing precis in school. The idea is to make the paragraph as short as you can without losing its essential meaning. An example would be: “The Inns of Court - and there are four of them - are the professional associations for barristers in England. Every barrister in England must belong to one of the Inns and they have been around since the late 1300s. If you are ever in London with a little bit of time to spare, head over to Chancery Lane or walk up from Victoria Embankment. Enter the Inns of Court and you’ll find yourself in what feels like a city within a city, a pefect little world, tucked just out of sight.” (From “Essentially England News”). The precis: In England, every barrister must belong to one of London’s four Inns of Court, which can be reached along Chancery Lane or by walking to them along the Victoria Embankment. Established in the late 1300s, it’s been described as a perfect little world, just out of sight and feels like a city within a city.

I know two ways. One is to read the subject document, while taking a few notes, and then to describe what’s in the document accurately and completely, getting down all the essentials — as if you were describing your vacation to a friend. The other way is to succinctly restate the content of two or three-sentence blocks, sort of like taking notes in a college lecture. Then you revisit your restatement to remove less important material and make it shorter and shorter. The first method has the disadvantage that in a document of any length at all it requires a brilliant mind — unless you are already an expert in the subject matter of the document it can be difficult to hold all its important information in your mind at once. The second method has the disadvantage that it is very time consuming, like digging a hole with a toothpick.

I am assuming that you want to be “precise”. In 7th grade we had an assignment to write instructions on how to walk up stairs or make a peanut butter and jelly sandwich…something everybody knows how to do. Think about all the steps involved and write them down in order, then actually physically do what you wrote. Did you come up with the result you intended? Did you forget something? Being precise means answering all the questions for someone reading your instructions, before they have time to think of them.
